99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:16): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Skeleton is a "codec" to embed meta information about streams into Ogg
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:17): Ogg will carry anything and for some applications it's useful to have information in place what *exactly* is in some multiplexed Ogg thingie
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:17): one nice property of CMML is that it's not just Ogg only
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (09:17): is there a simple diagram or flowchart that shows how the Ogg Container format, Ogg Vorbis, Ogg Theora, Ogg Skeleton, CMML and whatever else fit together?
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:17): (I love Ogg, but one cannot expect it to be the only game around)
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:18): not that I'm aware of, but here it is in a nutshell:
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:18): - Ogg: simply a container, lightweight, low overhead
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:19): - Ogg Skeleton: a "codec" delivered by Ogg carrying information about other encapsulated streams (MIME-type etc. and whatnot)
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:19): - Ogg Vorbis and Ogg Theora are the most common codecs for audio (Vorbis) and video (Theora)
99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:20): - CMML in Ogg is "serialized" CMML embedded as multiplexed stream in Ogg

99a3bfa1a9430e7df6358b5f3e9e1e17 (09:23): actually the most common video files around are plain Ogg with just Theora and Vorbis multiplexed. One does neither need Skeleton nor CMML for basic video + audio
